entry.et: Middle English anoien, from Anglo-French anuier, ennoier, from Late Latin inodiare to make loathsome, from Latin in + odium hatred odium

def.dt: :to disturb or irritate especially by repeated acts
:to harass especially by quick brief attacks

entry.pt: annoy vex irk bother mean to upset a person's composure. annoy implies a wearing on the nerves by persistent petty unpleasantness their constant complaining annoys us. vex implies greater provocation and stronger disturbance and usually connotes anger but sometimes perplexity or anxiety vexed by her son's failure to clean his room. irk stresses difficulty in enduring and the resulting weariness or impatience of spirit careless waste irks the boss. bother suggests interference with comfort or peace of mind don't bother me while I'm reading.
